title: Kerning in InDesign
content:
My Quark officially bit the dust yesterday so I am finally jumping ship.

I have been using InDesign (ID) for \<24h.

From my experience in the old days, I understand that when creating a typeface in a piece of software like Fontographer, you could pre-determine kerning pairs.

In ID, when I look at the kerning options, there are three choices:

1. Optical  
2. Metrics  
3. None

I understand that optical takes advantage of an algorythm in ID which attempts to counterbalance the negative space between glyphs based upon the typeface itself. Serif’s and all.

It is very important that I recreate materials using the type designers original kerning pairs, not ID’s interpretation of what it considers “good” kerning to be, and not all kerning pair set to zero.

Repeat, I need the text to be set using the original type designers kerning pairs.

Do I do this by using “metrics” or “none?”

Adobe technical support was unable to answer this question.

Thank you.

comments.content:
I’m pretty sure metrics uses the font’s built-in kerning pairs.

David

<cite>Adobe technical support was unable to answer this question.</cite>

I am stunned. [The online help](http://web.archive.org/web/20081203235603/http:/livedocs.adobe.com/en_US/InDesign/5.0/help.html?content=WSa285fff53dea4f8617383751001ea8cb3f-6e0a.html) explains it quite obviously, and under the help item “Kerning and tracking” as well!

In short, **Optical** uses ID’s build in system, and — reportedly — works best with large type. It kinda gets slow for running text, but according to people in the know, it adds too much space.

**None** puts no extra space inbetween characters (or takes it out), so, essentially, all that’s left is the space that’s in the letter boxes itself. Kind of what you’re seeing in your browser.

**Metrics** “uses kern pairs, which are included with most fonts” (yeah, that’s what the help sez!), and this is what you obviously want: just what the designer decided, no more no less.

For Quark there was this plugin (oh yeah, sorry: ’XTension’) that allowed you to create custom kern tables for fonts, but sadly, ID lacks this and nobody who can write plugins cares enough to write one.
